questions.questionText: What is the primary responsibility of a brokerage firm in financial matters?
options: A) Maximize profits for the firm
B) Ensure compliance with legal consumer protection laws
C) Share transaction fees with licensees
D) Open trust accounts for personal funds
questions.explanation: Firms must protect consumers and follow all applicable laws.

questions.questionText: What is an IBRETA account used for?
options: A) Holding licensee salaries
B) Holding client funds in real estate transactions
C) Managing non-client funds for escrow purposes
D) Storing the firm’s operational funds
questions.explanation: An IBRETA account is specifically designed for client funds.

questions.questionText: What is the maximum amount of personal funds a firm can keep in a trust account?
questions.explanation: Up to $300 can be deposited to cover service charges.

questions.questionText: How many types of real estate trust accounts are there?
options: A) One
B) Two
C) Three
D) Four
questions.explanation: Trust accounts include IBRETA, interest-bearing for non-client funds, and non-interest-bearing for non-client funds.

questions.questionText: How long does a firm have to notify the DSPS after opening a trust account?
options: A) 5 days
B) 10 days
C) 15 days
D) 30 days
questions.explanation: Notification must occur within 10 days to ensure compliance.

questions.questionText: What must a trust account include in its name?
options: A) The firm owner’s name
B) The firm’s name and the words "trust account"
C) The account holder’s signature
D) A DSPS registration number
questions.explanation: Trust accounts must include the firm’s name and the designation "trust account."

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of a trust account?
options: A) Holding non-refundable fees
B) Managing real estate trust funds for transactions
C) Securing brokerage firm assets
D) Paying commission to agents
questions.explanation: Trust accounts are used to hold real estate trust funds such as earnest money.

questions.questionText: What does FDIC insure?
options: A) Brokerage commissions
B) Real estate transactions
C) Deposits in eligible trust accounts
D) Loan repayments
questions.explanation: FDIC provides insurance for deposits in trust accounts up to a limit.

questions.questionText: What must be done if a trust account check is returned for insufficient funds?
options: A) Notify the buyer immediately
B) Close the trust account
C) Withdraw additional funds from another trust account
D) Notify the DSPS
questions.explanation: The client must be informed and decide on next steps.

questions.questionText: Who can sign checks for a trust account?
options: A) Only licensed brokers
B) Any authorized individual 18 years or older
C) Only the firm owner
D) Only the transaction’s buyer
questions.explanation: Authorized signatories do not have to be licensees.

questions.questionText: How soon must earnest money be deposited into a trust account?
options: A) Immediately
B) Within 24 hours
C) Within 48 hours
D) Within one week
questions.explanation: Funds must be deposited within 48 hours to comply with regulations.

questions.questionText: What happens to interest earned on IBRETA accounts?
options: A) It is distributed to the firm’s employees
B) It is donated to homeless assistance programs
C) It is kept by the client
D) It is used to pay DSPS fees
questions.explanation: Interest earned on IBRETA accounts supports homelessness programs.

questions.questionText: What is a non-depositable item in a real estate transaction?
options: A) A cashier’s check
B) A personal check
C) A vehicle title used as collateral
D) Cash payments
questions.explanation: Non-depositable items like vehicle titles cannot be held in trust accounts.

questions.questionText: What must be included on every trust account check?
options: A) The firm's logo
B) The words “trust account”
C) A transaction number
D) The supervising broker’s signature
questions.explanation: Trust account checks must clearly indicate their purpose.

questions.questionText: What is the role of a firm in escrow agreements for earnest money?
options: A) Drafting the agreement
B) Holding earnest money
C) Referring parties to an attorney for drafting
D) Collecting interest on escrowed funds
questions.explanation: Firms cannot draft escrow agreements and must refer parties to an attorney.

questions.questionText: What should a licensee do when selling personally owned property?
options: A) Deposit earnest money into a personal bank account
B) Hold earnest money in a real estate trust account
C) Ignore earnest money rules
D) Allow the buyer to hold the earnest money
questions.explanation: Licensees must handle earnest money as trust funds.

questions.questionText: How are non-client funds for leases under one year categorized?
options: A) Real estate trust funds and client funds
B) Personal funds
C) Real estate trust funds but not client funds
D) Non-regulated funds
questions.explanation: These funds are not client funds but must still follow trust fund rules.

questions.questionText: What must be included in the bookkeeping system for a trust account?
options: A) Daily balance updates
B) A monthly trial balance and reconciliation
C) Only cash disbursements
D) Quarterly reviews by the DSPS
questions.explanation: Bookkeeping must include a monthly reconciliation and trial balance.

questions.questionText: What document must be submitted to the DSPS when opening a trust account?
options: A) A business plan
B) Consent to examine and audit trust account form
C) An IRS tax form
D) A personal financial statement
questions.explanation: This form authorizes the DSPS to examine trust accounts.

questions.questionText: Who benefits from the interest earned on client funds in an IBRETA account?
options: A) The brokerage firm
B) The state’s homeless assistance programs
C) The listing agent
D) The buyer
questions.explanation: Interest from IBRETA accounts is used for public benefit.

questions.questionText: What must a firm do if a buyer’s earnest money check bounces?
options: A) Hold the check until sufficient funds are available
B) Notify the buyer and seller immediately
C) Destroy the check
D) Reimburse the seller
questions.explanation: Both parties must be notified promptly of insufficient funds.

questions.questionText: How should a firm handle funds received that cannot be deposited?
options: A) Deposit them into a business account
B) Forward them to the payee within one business day
C) Hold them indefinitely
D) Return them to the buyer within 48 hours
questions.explanation: Funds that cannot be deposited must be forwarded or returned promptly.

questions.questionText: What is the definition of client funds under Wis. Stat. § 452.13?
options: A) Any payment related to leases under one year
B) Promissory notes held by the firm
C) Earnest money, down payments, or money related to conveyances
D) Fees paid directly to licensees
questions.explanation: Client funds specifically relate to conveyances and real estate transactions.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of a journal in trust account bookkeeping?
options: A) Recording a summary of monthly transactions
B) Recording the chronological sequence of all receipts and disbursements
C) Balancing the trial ledger
D) Filing tax returns
questions.explanation: The journal tracks all financial activities in chronological order.

questions.questionText: What does a title insurance policy protect against?
options: A) Market fluctuations
B) Defects, liens, or encumbrances in the title
C) Property damage
D) Zoning changes
questions.explanation: Title insurance ensures a clear and marketable title.

questions.questionText: What is the standard method of proration for real estate taxes?
options: A) Based on the seller's estimate
B) Divided equally between buyer and seller
C) Using the previous year’s tax bill as a reference
D) Calculated by the DSPS
questions.explanation: Parties typically use the previous year’s tax bill for proration.

questions.questionText: What is required to clear a construction lien exception?
options: A) Proof of mortgage payments
B) A contractor’s lien waiver
C) A title insurance policy
D) Payment of the buyer’s closing costs
questions.explanation: Lien waivers confirm no outstanding construction liens.

questions.questionText: What does an owner’s affidavit typically address?
options: A) Payment of earnest money
B) Contractor work and parties in possession
C) Title insurance premiums
D) Closing fees and commissions
questions.explanation: The affidavit addresses lien and possession issues.

questions.questionText: What does a gap endorsement cover?
options: A) Errors in the seller’s disclosure
B) Liens or claims arising between the title commitment date and deed recording
C) Boundary disputes
D) Loan defaults
questions.explanation: A gap endorsement protects against issues during this period.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of a closing statement?
options: A) To confirm the listing agent’s commission
B) To outline financial details of the transaction
C) To assign repair responsibilities
D) To verify inspection results
questions.explanation: The closing statement summarizes the transaction’s financial details.

questions.questionText: What must a firm do before closing a trust account?
options: A) Notify the DSPS within 15 days
B) Ensure all funds are disbursed or transferred
C) Submit a final audit to the DSPS
D) Obtain written approval from all clients
questions.explanation: A trust account cannot be closed until all funds are disbursed or transferred.

questions.questionText: How should a firm handle trust account funds from a rejected offer?
options: A) Retain the funds until further instructions
B) Deposit them in a temporary holding account
C) Return them to the payer or forward them to the payee within one business day
D) Transfer them to the firm’s operational account
questions.explanation: Funds from a rejected offer must be returned or forwarded promptly.

questions.questionText: What is the required action if a firm receives a non-depositable item as earnest money?
options: A) Hold it in the firm’s safe until the transaction closes
B) Deposit it in a separate non-depositable account
C) Return it to the buyer or direct them to an escrow agent
D) Convert it to a check and deposit in the trust account
questions.explanation: Firms cannot hold non-depositable items; parties must handle them separately.

questions.questionText: What must be included in the ledger for each transaction?
options: A) The supervising broker’s signature
B) A running balance, transaction details, and party names
C) Monthly reconciliations
D) The DSPS certification number for the trust account
questions.explanation: Ledgers must detail receipts, disbursements, and balances for each transaction.

questions.questionText: What does a title insurance policy protect against?
options: A) Market fluctuations
B) Defects, liens, or encumbrances in the title
C) Property damage
D) Zoning changes
questions.explanation: Title insurance ensures a clear and marketable title.

questions.questionText: What is the standard method of proration for real estate taxes?
options: A) Based on the seller's estimate
B) Divided equally between buyer and seller
C) Using the previous year’s tax bill as a reference
D) Calculated by the DSPS
questions.explanation: Parties typically use the previous year’s tax bill for proration.

questions.questionText: What is required to clear a construction lien exception?
options: A) A lien waiver from the seller
B) A gap endorsement purchased by the seller
C) A survey of the property
D) Proof of no outstanding taxes
questions.explanation: The gap exception is cleared with a gap endorsement.

questions.questionText: What must a firm do if it holds a promissory note related to a transaction?
options: A) Deposit it in the trust account
B) Record it in the ledger but not include it in the balance
C) Include it in the monthly trial balance
D) Send it to the DSPS for approval
questions.explanation: Promissory notes are recorded in the ledger but not included in the running balance.

questions.questionText: What action can a firm take if parties fail to agree on disbursing earnest money after 60 days?
options: A) Disburse funds at the firm's discretion
B) Retain the funds indefinitely
C) File an interpleader action or seek an attorney’s opinion
D) Transfer funds to the DSPS
questions.explanation: After 60 days, firms may seek legal resolution or an attorney's written opinion.

questions.questionText: What can a firm do with trust account records if switching to computerized bookkeeping?
options: A) Retain paper records only for the past year
B) Ensure all entries are backed up daily on a separate medium
C) Submit records to the DSPS for review
D) Use manual systems alongside computerized methods
questions.explanation: Computerized records must have daily backups to comply with regulations.

questions.questionText: What must a firm do before disbursing earnest money based on an attorney's opinion?
options: A) Obtain DSPS approval
B) Notify all parties by certified mail 30 days in advance
C) Ensure the opinion favors the firm
D) Have the attorney represent one of the parties
questions.explanation: Parties must receive 30 days' notice before disbursement based on an attorney's opinion.

questions.questionText: What type of funds are not considered client funds under Wis. Stat. § 452.13?
options: A) Earnest money
B) Promissory notes
C) Security deposits for leases over one year
D) Down payments
questions.explanation: Promissory notes are not client funds as they are not liquid payments.

questions.questionText: What information is required when notifying the DSPS of a new trust account?
options: A) The firm owner’s name and license number
B) The account name, number, and depository institution
C) The anticipated annual balance
D) The firm’s total number of trust accounts
questions.explanation: Notification must include detailed account information and institution details.

questions.questionText: How should a firm handle escrow agreements for after-closing obligations?
options: A) Draft the agreement using a WB form
B) Refer the parties to an attorney
C) Hold the funds in the firm’s operational account
D) Use the standard REEB-approved after-closing escrow form
questions.explanation: Wisconsin does not approve a specific form for after-closing escrow agreements.

questions.questionText: What is required to remove the gap exception in a title insurance policy?
options: A) A lien waiver from the seller
B) A gap endorsement purchased by the seller
C) A survey of the property
D) Proof of no outstanding taxes
questions.explanation: The gap exception is cleared with a gap endorsement.

questions.questionText: What must a firm do if it holds a promissory note related to a transaction?
options: A) Deposit it in the trust account
B) Record it in the ledger but not include it in the balance
C) Include it in the monthly trial balance
D) Send it to the DSPS for approval
questions.explanation: Promissory notes are recorded in the ledger but not included in the running balance.

questions.questionText: What action can a firm take if parties fail to agree on disbursing earnest money after 60 days?
options: A) Disburse funds at the firm's discretion
B) Retain the funds indefinitely
C) File an interpleader action or seek an attorney’s opinion
D) Transfer funds to the DSPS
questions.explanation: After 60 days, firms may seek legal resolution or an attorney's written opinion.

questions.questionText: What can a firm do with trust account records if switching to computerized bookkeeping?
options: A) Retain paper records only for the past year
B) Ensure all entries are backed up daily on a separate medium
C) Submit records to the DSPS for review
D) Use manual systems alongside computerized methods
questions.explanation: Computerized records must have daily backups to comply with regulations.

questions.questionText: What must a firm do before disbursing earnest money based on an attorney's opinion?
options: A) Obtain DSPS approval
B) Notify all parties by certified mail 30 days in advance
C) Ensure the opinion favors the firm
D) Have the attorney represent one of the parties
questions.explanation: Parties must receive 30 days' notice before disbursement based on an attorney's opinion.

options: A) Earnest money
B) Promissory notes
C) Security deposits for leases over one year
D) Down payments
questions.explanation: Promissory notes are not client funds as they are not liquid payments.

options: A) The firm owner’s name and license number
B) The account name, number, and depository institution
C) The anticipated annual balance
D) The firm’s total number of trust accounts
questions.explanation: Notification must include detailed account information and institution details.

options: A) Draft the agreement using a WB form
B) Refer the parties to an attorney
C) Hold the funds in the firm’s operational account
D) Use the standard REEB-approved after-closing escrow form
questions.explanation: Wisconsin does not approve a specific form for after-closing escrow agreements.

options: A) A lien waiver from the seller

D) Proof of no outstanding taxes

D) Transfer funds to the DSPS

questions.explanation: Wisconsin does not approve a specific form for after-closing escrow agreements.
